field_edited_text.value:
xisting Conditions

Industrial Activity: Four Hawkins Point
manufacturing firms employ approximately
1,600 persons. The largest W.R. Grace’s
Davison Chemical Division with 770
employees, produces automotive catalysts
as well as silicon derivative products. SCM
Corp.’s Glidden Pigments Group estab-
lished its operations in Hawkins Point in
1956 and today employs 676 persons. The
company produces titanium dioxide pig-
ments used in the manufacture of paints.
U.S. Gypsum Co. with 160 employees pro-
duces gypsum building material products,
receiving barge shipments of production
materials at its own pier. Finally, Atlantic
Cement with 12 employees produces
cement and concrete at its batching plant
located on Chemical Road.

Wholesale and trucking firms are also a
significant employer in Hawkins Point. Four
companies provide 105 jobs. The trucking
firms are concentrated south of Hawkins
Point Road along the City/County
boundary. e

>

Hawkins Point is also the location of
four landfill operations. Browning Ferris
Industries, Inc. and SCM Corp. operate
landfills on adjoining sites of 30.56 acres
and 37.95 acres respectively.

The Maryland Environmental Service
developed a facility to handle disposal of
hazardous waste on approximately eight
acres of land owned by the Maryland Port
Administration at Thom’s Cove. The facility
has now been designated to dispose of
chromium waste from Allied Chemical’s
plant in Baltimore City.

At the old Quarantine Station site the
Maryland Port Administration operates a
small facility to dispose of dredge spoil
material from projects in the harbor

Port Activity: Despite close proximity
to deep water channels, only one marine
terminal operates in Hawkins Point. The
terminal is owned by the Maryland Port
Administration and is leased to Eastalco
Aluminum Corporation which operates a
facility for receipt, storage, and shipment of
alumina to its smelting plant in Frederick
County, Maryland. The terminal includes a
30,000 ton silo used for storage of alumina
and a CSX Railroad line which provides
access to the pier. Twelve persons are
employed at the Eastalco Terminal.

Both W.R. Grace and U.S. Gypsum
receive a portion of their raw materials
through the use of private piers.



SCM Glidden’s paint pigment plant

Residential Areas: Hawkins Point has
historically never supported a very large
residential community. For a number of
years just over 100 residents occupied
homes on approximately five acres of
commercially zoned land between Hawkins
Point Road and the Baltimore Beltway.
With the development of the MES hazard-
ous waste disposal facility the State set up
funds to purchase these properties and
allow residents to relocate out of the area.
There are also several smaller clusters of
houses on streets south of Hawkins Point
Road.

Recreation Areas: Hawkins Point’s only
major recreation area is Fort Armistead,
built by the U.S. government in 1898 as one
of the forts to defend the harbor during
the Spanish American War. The fort is
named after Colonel George Armistead,
who served in the battle of Northpoint in
the War of 1812. Baltimore City acquired
the 46 acre tract from the government in
1927 with the provision that the land be
used exclusively for recreation purposes.

Approaching the fort from land there
is a rather large, flat bow! of land rising to
the remains of battlements. This drops
rapidly to a seawall which is built along the
entire shoreline. The remains of the fort
are dominated by concrete gun mounts,
platforms and ammunition storage
chambers below.

The view from the battlements and sea-
wall is exceptional. To the north and east
are Bethlehem Steel’s Sparrows Point Plant
and the confluence of the Patapsco River
and Chesapeake Bay. Dominating the view
to the west is the Francis Scott Key Bridge,
offering a unique view of ships passing
under the bridge.

Using special State funds, the City has
made major improvements to Fort Armi-
stead. A newly landscaped entrance road,
expanded parking for visitors and a boat
launch, a renovated pier and seawall, play
equipment and picnic areas were dedicated
in the summer of 1984. The park, although
not well known, is well used for free boat
launching, fishing, and by people who
simply enjoy watching the port’s activities.



438
